M.G.L. c. 186.proposition: This action arises under Massachusetts landlord-tenant law, including the covenant of quiet enjoyment implied in residential tenancies, and related statutory and regulatory provisions concerning habitability. Venue and jurisdiction are proper in Brockton District Court because the rental premises are located in Brockton, Massachusetts. See M.G.L. c. 186; M.G.L. c. 239.

M.G.L. c. 239.proposition: This action arises under Massachusetts landlord-tenant law, including the covenant of quiet enjoyment implied in residential tenancies, and related statutory and regulatory provisions concerning habitability. Venue and jurisdiction are proper in Brockton District Court because the rental premises are located in Brockton, Massachusetts. See M.G.L. c. 186; M.G.L. c. 239.

Rodgers v. Superior Court.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in residential tenancies and prohibits a landlord from substantially interfering with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of the leased premises. See, e.g., Restatement (Second) of Property: Landlord & Tenant § 12.1 (implied covenant of quiet enjoyment); see also Massachusetts caselaw recognizing that a landlord’s failure to provide essential utilities or services may constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment (and render the landlord liable for damages and abatement). See, e.g., Rodgers v. Superior Court, and other principles discussed below.

M.G.L. c. 111.proposition: Massachusetts statutes and regulations require landlords to maintain rental housing in compliance with applicable sanitary and housing codes and to provide essential services necessary for habitability. See, e.g., M.G.L. c. 111 (Public Health), M.G.L. c. 186 (Landlord & Tenant), and the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 (Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation; Housing). See also M.G.L. c. 239 (summary process and rents) for related procedural provisions.

105 CMR 410.000.proposition: Massachusetts statutes and regulations require landlords to maintain rental housing in compliance with applicable sanitary and housing codes and to provide essential services necessary for habitability. See, e.g., M.G.L. c. 111 (Public Health), M.G.L. c. 186 (Landlord & Tenant), and the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 (Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation; Housing). See also M.G.L. c. 239 (summary process and rents) for related procedural provisions.

M.G.L. c. 186, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\.proposition: (Representative statutory, regulatory, and case authorities recognizing landlord obligations and the covenant of quiet enjoyment; Plaintiff relies on these authorities to support the legal theory and requested relief)

M.G.L. c. 111, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\.proposition: (Representative statutory, regulatory, and case authorities recognizing landlord obligations and the covenant of quiet enjoyment; Plaintiff relies on these authorities to support the legal theory and requested relief)

M.G.L. c. 93A, \u00a7\u00a7 2 and 11.proposition: - M.G.L. c. 93A, §§ 2 and 11 (consumer protection statute) — cited as background and illustrative of unlawful business practices in landlord-tenant relations (not asserted as an independent count in this Complaint).

Clapp v. Van Slyke.proposition: - Clapp v. Van Slyke and other Massachusetts decisions recognizing that substantial interference with essential services may constitute breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment (see, e.g., cases collected in Massachusetts practice treatises and ALR annotations);

G. L. C. v. M. R., 378 Mass. 1 (1979).proposition: - G. L. C. v. M. R., 378 Mass. 1 (1979) (discussing landlord/tenant duties under state law and the significance of essential services — cited as representative state authority);
G. L. C. v. M. R., 378 Mass. 1 (1979).case_name: Good Hope Industries, Inc. v. Ryder Scott Co.
G. L. C. v. M. R., 378 Mass. 1 (1979).support_reasoning: The opinion in G. L. C. v. M. R. (actually Good Hope Industries, Inc. v. Ryder Scott Co.) concerns whether Massachusetts courts may exercise personal jurisdiction over a nonresident defendant under the state long‑arm statute, G. L. c. 223A, § 3(a). It does not address landlord/tenant law, duties of landlords or tenants, or the concept of essential services in a tenancy. Using this case as representative authority on landlord/tenant duties or essential services is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the opinion’s reasoning or holding.
G. L. C. v. M. R., 378 Mass. 1 (1979).relevant_excerpt: “Generally, a claim of personal jurisdiction over a nonresident defendant presents a two-fold inquiry: (1) is the assertion of jurisdiction authorized by statute, and (2) if authorized, is the exercise of jurisdiction under State law consistent with basic due process requirements mandated by the United States Constitution? … Having examined the facts before us, we are satisfied that c. 223A, § 3(a), within its literal and constitutional boundaries, confers jurisdiction in this case.”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 389 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 389 Mass. 178 (1983)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 389 Mas.proposition: - Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 389 Mass. 178 (1983) (discussing landlord obligations to maintain habitability/health conditions — representative SJC authority);
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 389 Mas.support_reasoning: This opinion is a Massachusetts SJC tax case about whether a nonresident is subject to Massachusetts income tax on interest from an installment sale of Massachusetts real estate. It does not discuss landlord-tenant law, landlord obligations, or the implied warranty of habitability. The proposition confuses this case with the well‑known landlord‑tenant decision also titled Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway from 1973; this 1983 citation (389 Mass. 178) is unrelated to habitability or health conditions.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 389 Mas.relevant_excerpt: The question presented by this appeal is whether a nonresident who elects for Federal and State income tax purposes to pay tax on an instalment basis on a gain from the sale of Massachusetts real estate... is subject to Massachusetts income tax under G. L. c. 62, § 63, on the interest earned on the instalment obligation note.

Emanuel v. Peoria.proposition: - Emanuel v. Peoria, Mass. App. Ct. decisions recognizing rent abatement and damages for interruption of essential services (representative appellate decisions applying covenant principles);
